metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.code_html:
module mymodule {
  requires module1;
  requires transitive module2;
  requires static module3;
}

content.text: The requires keyword is a module directive that specifies a different module which this module depends on.
content.html: The requires keyword is a module directive that specifies a different module which this module depends on.

content.text: There are two modifiers which can be added to the requires directive: transitive and static
content.html: There are two modifiers which can be added to the requires directive: transitive and static

content.text: The transitive modifier allows other modules to use this module without also having to declare this same requirement.
content.html: The transitive modifier allows other modules to use this module without also having to declare this same requirement.

content.text: The static modifier makes the requirement optional during runtime. It allows this module to run even if the other module is not present.
content.html: The static modifier makes the requirement optional during runtime. It allows this module to run even if the other module is not present.

content.text: Note: The requires keyword is a module directive meant to be used in the module-info.java file of a module.
content.html: Note: The requires keyword is a module directive meant to be used in the module-info.java file of a module.

content.text: The requires keyword was new in Java 9.
